en: Interview with Brenda Evans, volunteer with Samaritan's Purse, conducted by Casey Kaufman. Evans provides a background on Samaritan's Purse and her time with the organization. She discusses the efforts made by her and her team at Gatlinburg to help families by sifting through the ashes of destroyed homes for any salvageable posessions. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: "That's what I think they find so amazing is that the majority of us love what we do, love the Lord and wants them to see that, and bring them some joy in a time when they're miserable."

Interview with Brenda Evans, volunteer with Samaritan's Purse, conducted by Casey Kaufman. Evans provides a background on Samaritan's Purse and her time with the organization. She discusses the efforts made by her and her team at Gatlinburg to help families by sifting through the ashes of destroyed homes for any salvageable posessions. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: "That's what I think they find so amazing is that the majority of us love what we do, love the Lord and wants them to see that, and bring them some joy in a time when they're miserable."

Can you tell us your name and a little about your background?
Can you tell us some about the other disaster areas you have worked in?
For people not familiar with Samaritan's Purse, can you tell us about their mission and what drew you to them?
What were your experiences in the weeks leading up to the wildfire?
Would you tell us about what transpired after receiving the call from Samaritan's Purse?
Where was the site headquarters located?
Can you walk us through your day to day experience at the site?
Do the homeowners know when you are on the way?
How many people are typically on a team?
Did you find anything other than the rings at this particular job site?
How many work orders did you do in Gatlinburg? How many families?
How do people feel even if you are unable to find anything in the remains?
How soon after the fire were you going in? Were some of the victims still living in shelters?
What kind of impact do you think Samaritan's Purse had on these homeowners?
What kind of impact do you feel that working in Gatlinburg, which is close to your home, had on you?
Can you elaborate on how you see the Gatlinburg community, or some specific people, recovering a few years out?
Did you ever see any community friction after the wildfire?
Do you feel that people are prepared for a future disaster?
Is there anything surprising or good that came from this?

seo.title: Interview with Brenda Evans, 2020-06-11 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories

Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
